awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Mitigation strategies for enhancing performance while maintaining viability in cyber-physical systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex cyber-physical systems (CPS) that operate in dynamic and uncertain environments will inevitably encounter unanticipated situations during their operation.  Examples range from naturally occurring faults in both the cyber and physical components to attacks launched by malicious entities with the purpose of disrupting normal operations. As infrastructures, e.g. energy, transportation, industrial systems and built environments, are getting smarter, the chance of a fault or attack increases. When this happens, it is essential that system behavior remains viable, i.e., it does not violate pre-specified operating constraints on run-time behavior. Preserving safety, for instance, is of paramount importance to avoid damage and possible loss of life. This project will develop strategies for mitigating the effects of such unanticipated situations, that seek to optimize for performance (measured by multiple metrics such as cost, efficiency, accuracy, etc.) without compromising viability.  The emphasis will be on the automotive application domain, given the upcoming revolution brought by innovations such as vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V), vehicle to infrastructure (V2I) communication and autonomous driving, and because of the safety-criticality of the transportation infrastructure. To ground our research on relevant problems, we will engage industrial partners. The outcomes of the project will be validated upon test scenarios drawn from the automotive industry.  

Fundamental issues arising when safety-critical CPS operate in uncertain environments will be addressed, with the objective of obtaining a better understanding of, and developing optimal or near-optimal strategies for dealing with, emergent problems that arise from the interaction of resource-allocation and control strategies in such systems. One of the novelties of the technical approach adopted in this project is to closely integrate three different CPS perspectives control theory, automotive & aerospace application domain-knowledge, and real-time resource management & scheduling in order to develop run-time mitigation strategies for complex CPS's operating in dynamic and uncertain environments, and exposed to a variety of faults. Such an integrated approach will allow for the identification of emergent problems that arise from the interaction of resource-allocation and control algorithms, that may otherwise remain undiscovered if the control and resource-allocation aspects were considered separately.
The general design-time and run-time tools for creating resilient CPSs will be guided by the implementation and evaluation of the research in simulation and on laboratory test-beds upon three applications from the automotive domain: fault resilience for variable-valve internal combustion engines; fail-safe energy management for hybrid-electric vehicles; and robust sensor management for autonomous vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development of mitigation strategies for assuring system viability despite contingencies (such as faults) that are relevant in engineering applications. 

Notably, novel methods have been developed for actuator failure mode management, detection, and isolation which ensure that safety constraints can be enforced when operating in the normal and failure modes and during mode transitions.  In particular, a set-theoretic failure mode and effect management (FMEM) strategy was developed to handle jammed (stuck in a constant position) actuators; this strategy exploits nesting of constraint admissible sets for the closed-loop system augmented with the reference governor in the previous mode within the recoverable sets, that are the sets of states that can be recovered by prescribed length command sequences, in any possible subsequent mode.  This approach was extended also to the stochastic setting with chance constraints and non-instantaneous mode detection and isolation; for this case, we proposed a scheme based on the integration of the multi-model adaptive estimator and an "At Once Reference Governor (AORG)" that generates the recovery sequence to not only satisfy constraints but to also optimize fault detection performance. 

To facilitate the implementation of FMEM schemes, new methods exploiting sums of squares programming were developed for computing maximum output admissible sets (MOAS) and for computing the Pontryagin difference between basic semi-algebraic sets. Two procedures for overbounding the finite determination index of MOAS for systems with and without disturbance have been established; these procedures are fast and enable the computation of MOAS online for systems that could have undergone degradations or failures. Methods utilizing machine learning have been additionally proposed for reference governor construction. A Stochastic Controller State and Reference Governor (S-CSRG) has been developed that can reset dynamic controller states and adjust reference commands to satisfy probabilistic chance constraints, including during failure modes.

In addition to the above, we developed Model Predictive Control (MPC) solutions to maximize system viability, e.g., maintain for as long as possible a system operating without safety constraint violation in situations when eventual constraint violation is inevitable. Notably, our approach applies to nonlinear models and is based on a nonlinear programming formulation with purely continuous variables; it is thus more computationally tractable for higher order models versus previously proposed approaches based on dynamic programming (DP) and mixed integer programming (MIP).  For linear models and constraints, computations reduce to solving a linear programming (LP) problem.  

Another viability maximization problem was treated for an agent that wishes to avoid detection by another agent while pursuing its own objective. In this setting, the fault corresponded to being detected by this other agent.  This problem was formulated and treated in a Markov decision process framework where to gain scalability to larger-sized problems, a receding-horizon optimization approach was developed to compute approximate solutions.  

Additionally, methods grounded in the use of an artificial generator system have been developed for time-varying stabilization of systems with tight and even one sided control constraints and for finite and prescribed time stabilization of drift free affine in control nonlinear systems which are not smoothly or even continuously stabilizable by time-invariant feedback.

Finally, the potential for practical benefits of the theoretical advances was highlighted through application-oriented case studies.

In particular, an MPC algorithm was developed for traffic lights to alleviate traffic congestion and enable safe and timely passage of emergency vehicles. Simulation results illustrated the reduction in travel times of emergency vehicles through either centralized or distributed control of traffic lights with MPC, without leading to unacceptable congestion in other lanes.  In addition, our FMEM and MPC approaches have been demonstrated in aircraft flight simulations, including for aircraft upset recovery from oscillatory spin and steep spiral conditions, for vision-based landing, and for maneuver load alleviation.

The potential for applications of drift counteraction optimal control based on stochastic dynamic programming for flight time maximization has been demonstrated for fuel cell hybrid electric small UAV.   

Another stochastic predictive control approach based on minimizing the time-joint state constraint violation probability was developed for drone routing to maximize the viability of the drone delivery of medical products. Solutions were also developed for fuel efficient maintenance of spacecraft on Halo orbits in cislunar space and for safe forced merging of automated vehicles into a dense traffic of human driven vehicles. Set-theoretic localization algorithms synergistic with the applications of set-theoretic methods for detecting and isolating faults have been experimentally implemented on RC cars at the University of Michigan. 

This project enabled the training and professional growth of several PhD and Masters’ students and benefitted from vibrant collaboration with researchers at Washington University in St. Louis which led to multiple joint publications. The students involved supported departmental outreach programs such as the Quadcopter Quidditch at the University of Michigan.  The results have been disseminated through conference and journal publications and several talks, and software was published in IEEE Code Ocean.
